name: Abbey Ale
best_for: Belgian Trappist Ale, Spiced Ale, Trippel, Dubbel, Grand Cru
notes: Used in two of six remaining Trappist breweries.  Distinctive plum and fruitiness.  Good for high gravity beers.

name: American Ale
best_for: American Pale Ale, Scottish Ale, Porters, Sweet Stout, Barley Wine, Alt
notes: Soft, smooth, clean finish.  Very well balanced.  Very versitile -- works well with many ale styles.

name: American Ale II
best_for: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine
notes: Clean, tart, nutty flavor.  More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.

name: American Hefeweizen Ale
best_for: Oregon style American Hefeweizen
notes: Produces a much smaller amount of clove and banana flavor than the German Hefeweizen White Labs yeast.  Some sulfur, and creates desired cloudy look.

name: American Lager Yeast
best_for: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.
notes: Dry and clean with very slight apple fruitiness.  Minimal sulfer and diacetyl.

name: American Lager
best_for: American Lagers and Pilsners
notes: Bold, with a complex aroma.  Good flavor depth characteristics for a wide variety of lager beers.

name: American Megabrewery
best_for: Light, Clean American style lagers.
notes: Smooth yeast with a slight fruity flavor.  Lagers into a smooth, clean tasting beer.  Use for light, clean lager styles with unobtrusive yeast character.

name: American Microbrewery Ale #1
best_for: American Ales, Cream Ales
notes: Smooth, clean, strong fermenting ale yeast that works well at cold temperature.  Clean malt flavor is ideal for cream ales.

name: American Microbrewery Ale #2
best_for: American ales
notes: Accentuated, rich, creamy malt profile.  Generous amounts of diacytl.  Use for low gravity beers where malt character is needed or stronger beers for a robust character.

name: American Microbrewery Lager
best_for: All lager styles
notes: Strong fermenter. Leaves a clean, full flavored, malty finish.  Slightly attenuative.  Versatile for most lager styles with a clean full flavor.

name: American Wheat Ale
best_for: American Wheat, Berlin Weiss, Hefeweizen
notes: Dry, Crisp, tart beer in the American Hefeweizen style.  Low flocculation aids in producing desired chill haze.

name: American White Ale
best_for: Hefe-Weizen, American Wheat
notes: Smooth wheat yeast with a round, clean, malt flavor.  Low flocculation leaves cloudy Hefe-Weizen finish.  Smooth flavor makes a great unfiltered wheat beer.

name: Australian Ale Yeast
best_for: Australian Ales, English Ales
notes: White Labs entry for Australian Ales.  Produces a clean, malty finish with pleasant ester character.  Bready character.  Can ferment clean at high temperatures.

name: Bastogne Belgian Ale
best_for: High gravity beers, Belgian ales, Dubbels, Trippels.
notes: High gravity Trappist ale yeast.  Creates a dry beer with a slightly acidic finish.  Cleaner finish and slightly less spicy than WLP500 or WLP530.

name: Bavarian Lager
best_for: German Bocks, Vienna, Oktoberfest, Hells, Marzens, Dunkel
notes: Use by many German breweries.  Produces a full-bodied, rich, malty beer.

name: Bavarian Weizen Yeast
best_for: Bavarian Weizen and wheat beers.
notes: Former yeast lab W51 strain.  Produces a classic German style wheat beer with moderately high, spicy, phenolic overtones reminiscent of cloves.

name: Bavarian Wheat
best_for: Bavarian Weizen, Hefeweizen
notes: Hefeweizen yeast with complex flavor and aroma.  Bubble gum, banana flavors with apple/plub ester profile.  Malty flavor.

name: Bavarian Wheat Yeast
best_for: Bavarian style wheat beers.
notes: Blend of top-fermenting ale and wheat yeasts providing a mild ester and phenolic profile.

name: Bedford British Ale
best_for: English style ales - bitter, pale, porter and brown ale
notes: High attenuation. Ferments dry with high flocculation. Distinctive ester profile.  Good for most English ale styles.

name: Belgian Abbey II
best_for: Belgian Ales, Trappist Ales, Abbey Ales, Grand Cru
notes: Dry flavor with slight fruitiness. High alcohol tolerance.

name: Belgian Ale
best_for: Belgian Ales, Saisons, Belgian Reds, Belgian Browns, White beers
notes: Phenolic and spicy flavors.  Complex profile, with less fruitiness than White's Trappist Ale strain.

name: Belgian Ale Yeast
best_for: Belgian Ales, Abbey Ales, Trappist Ales
notes: Trappist style ale yeast.  Complex estery flavor.

name: Belgian Ale #1
best_for: Belgian Ales, High gravity ales.
notes: Produces classic Belgian ale flavor.  Robust, estery with notes of clove and fruit. Ferments well in high gravity worts.

name: Belgian Ale #2
best_for: Flanders style Belgian Ales, Belgian Brown, Fruit beers
notes: Flanders style yeast.  Strong fermenting yeast attenuates well and produces fruity, malty, estery malt profile.  Slow to flocculate.

name: Belgian Ale #3
best_for: Belgian ales, Trappist Ales
notes: Slightly more refined than CL-300.  Produces the classic Trappist ale character with esters of spice and fruit. Mildly phenolic.  Strong fermenting yeast.

name: Belgian Ardennes
best_for: Belgian Ale
notes: Phenolics develop at increased temperature.  Mild fruitiness and complex spicy flavor.

name: Belgian Golden Ale
best_for: Belgian Ales, Dubbel, Grand Cru, Belgian Holiday Ale
notes: Combination of fruitiness and phenolic characters dominate the profile.  Some sulfur which will dissapate following fermentation.

name: Belgian Lambic Blend
best_for: Belgian Lambic
notes: Lambic culture of Saccharomyces Cerevisiar and a mixture of yeasts and bacterias.  Blend of organisms helps create lactic flavor of Belgian Lambics.

name: Belgian Saison
best_for: Belgian Saison beer
notes: Classic farmhouse ale yeast.  Spicy, complex aromatics including bubble gum.  Tart and dry on the palate with mild fruitiness.  Finishes crisp and mildly acidic.  Ferment at warm temperature.  May have vigorous fermentation start.

name: Belgian Saison I Ale
best_for: Saison Ale, Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Trippel
notes: Saison yeast from Wallonia.  Earthy, spicy and peppery notes.  Slightly sweet.

name: Belgian Strong Ale
best_for: Belgian Ales, Scottish Strong Ale,Trappist Ales, Dubbels, Trippels
notes: Dry, tart, fruity flavor.  High alcohol tolerance.

name: Belgian Style Ale Yeast Blend
best_for: Trappist and other Belgian ales.
notes: Blend of two trappist ale yeasts and one Belgian ale yeast.  Creates a versatile blend to be used for Trappist and other Belgian style ales.

name: Belgian Wheat
best_for: Belgian Pils, Belgian Wit
notes: Top fermenting yeast with a soft bread-like character.  Leaves a sweet, mildly estery finish.  Delicious Belgian character to any beer.  Great in Wit style with coriander and bitter orange peel.

name: Belgian Wheat Yeast
best_for: Belgian Wheat, Bavarian Weizen
notes: Estery lor phenol yeast.  Plum and apple aroma with a dry finish.

name: Belgian Wit Ale
best_for: Belgian Wit
notes: Phenolic and tart.  The original yeast used to produce Wit in Belgium.

name: Belgian Wit II
best_for: Belgian Wit, Spiced Ale, Wheat Ales and Specialty Beers
notes: Less phenolic than WLP400 (Belgian Wit Ale) but more spicy.  Leaves a little more sweetness and flocculation is higher than WLP400.

name: Belgian Witbier
best_for: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru
notes: Tart, slightly phenolic character.  For Wits and Grand Cru.  Tolerates high gravity beers well.

name: Bohemian Lager
best_for: Bohemian Pilsners, Pilsners, German Helles, Bocks
notes: Ferments clean and malty, with rich malty flavor for full gravity pilsners.

name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
best_for: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns
notes: Wild yeast strain isolated from Brussels region of Belgium.  Adds classic sweaty horse hair flavor as well as sourness and cherry-pie like flavor.  Generally used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae after the primary fermentation has begun.  Requires 3-6 mo

name: Brettanomyces Lambicus
best_for: Belgian Lambic beers
notes: Wild yeast strain associated with Belgian breweries.  Contributes horsey, old leather flavor complex to Belgian lambics.  Slow growing yeast that takes weeks to ferment and months to develop fully.

name: British Ale
best_for: Excellent for all English style ales including bitters, pale ale, porters and brown ale.
notes: This yeast has higher attenuation than the White Labs English Ale yeast strains.  Produces a malty flavored beer.

name: British Ale Yeast
best_for: All British Ales, Pales, Bitters, English Strong Ale
notes: Fruity, tart, dry crisp finish.  Very well balanced.

name: British Ale II
best_for: British and Canadian Ales, English Bitters
notes: Malty, clean, crisp finish.  Dry flavor.

name: British Cask Ale
best_for: British Ales
notes: A great choice for any cask conditioned British Ale. Produces nice malt profile with a hint of fruit. Finishes dry and slightly tart.

name: British Draft Ale
best_for: Porters and Bitters.
notes: Full bodied, well rounded ale yeast with a touch of diacytl.  Emphasizes malt character.  Great for porters and bitters.

name: British Microbrewery Ale
best_for: English Bitters and Milds
notes: Complex oakey, and fruity ester profile.  Slightly under-attenuated finish leaves some residual malt flavor.  Suitable for low to medium gravity bitters and ales.

name: British Pale Ale #1
best_for: British Pale Ales and Bitters.
notes: Bold, citrusy character which accentuates mineral and hop flavors.  Distinct character of a classic Pale Ale.

name: British Pale Ale #2
best_for: British Pale Ale, other British Ales
notes: Smooth, full bodied, well roundd ale yeast. Mild esters.  Strong ferementer suitable for strong or spiced ales.  Accentuates caramel and malt flavors.

name: British Real Ale
best_for: Bitters and other English Ales
notes: Great for real pub bitters.  Has a complex, woody flavor and musty ester profile that characterizes real ale.  Underattenuating to leave mild sweetness to the finish.

name: Budvar Lager
best_for: Bohemian Pilsner, Classic Pilsners, Dortmunder and Light Lagers
notes: Classic pilsner lager yeast.  Malty nose and subtle fruit.  Rich malt profile, but dry crisp finish.  Hop character accentuated by dry finish.

name: Burton Ale
best_for: All English styles including Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout and Bitters.
notes: Burton-on-trent yeast produces a complex character.  Flavors include apple, pear, and clover honey.

name: California Ale
best_for: American Style Ales, Ambers, Pale Ales, Brown Ale, Strong Ale
notes: Very clean flavor, balance and stability.  Accentuates hop flavor Versitile - can be used to make any style ale.

name: California Ale V
best_for: American style Pales, Ambers, Browns, IPAs, American Strong Ale
notes: Similar to White Labs California Ale Yeast, but slightly lower attenuation leaves a fuller bodied beer.

name: California Esteem (Gold)
best_for: California Common Beer, American or Robust porters
notes: Use for California Common Beers (aka Steam Beer).  Leaves a slightly estery, well attenuated finish.  Quite distinct in flavor.  Can also be used for complex porters.

name: California Lager
best_for: California common beers, Steam Beer
notes: Suited for 19th century California style beers.  Lagers at high temperature and produces malty, clear beers.

name: Canadian Ale
best_for: Light Canadian Ales, Bitish Bitter, Pale Ale, Porters
notes: Clean, strong fermenting, well attenuated ale yeast that leaves a pleasant, fruity, complex finish.

name: Champagne Yeast
best_for: Wine, Mead and Cider
notes: Can tolerate alcohol up to 17%.  For Barley Wine or Meads.

name: Classic British Ale
best_for: Bitters, Porters, Scottish Heavy Ales.
notes: Complex ale with British tones and fruit like esters.  Works well in high gravity ales such as scottish heavy as well.

name: Cooper Ale
best_for: Most ales.
notes: General purpose dry ale yeast with a very good reputation.  Produces significant fruity flavors.  No phenolics.  Clean, fruity finish.

name: Cry Havoc
best_for: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.
notes: Licensed by White Labs from Charlie Papazian, author of "The Complete Joy of Home Brewing".  This yeast was used to brew many of his original recipes.  Diverse strain can ferment at ale and lager temps.

name: Czech Budejovice Lager
best_for: Bohemian Style Pilsner
notes: Dry and crisp with low diacetyl production.  From Southern Czech Republic.

name: Czech Pilsner Lager
best_for: Bohemian and American Pilsner, Bocks, Oktoberfest, Marzen
notes: Classic Pilsner strain.  Creates a dry but malty finish.  Perfect for Pilsners and bocks.  Some sulfur produced, but will fade with time.

name: Danish Lager
best_for: Dortmund/Export Lagers
notes: Rich, Dortmund style, with a crisp, dry finish.  Soft profile accentuates hop flavor.

name: Doric Ale
best_for: Ales
notes: Good reputation.  Reliable clean finish for a dry yeast.

name: Dry English Ale
best_for: Pale Ales, Amber, ESB, Brown Ales, Strong Ales
notes: Clean, Highly flocculant, and highly attentive yeast.  Similar to White labs English Ale yeast, but more attentive.  Suitable for high gravity ales.

name: Dusseldorf Alt Yeast
best_for: Alt biers, Dusseldorf Alts, German Ales
notes: Traditional Alt yeast from Dusseldorf, Germany.  Produces clean, slightly sweet alt beers.  Does not accentuate hop flavor like WLP029 does.

name: East Coast Ale
best_for: American Ales, Golden ales, Blonde Ale, Pale Ale and German Alt styles
notes: White labs "Brewer Patriot" strain can be used to reproduce many of the American versions of classic beer styles.  Very clean with low esters.

name: East European Lager
best_for: Marzens, Oktoberfest
notes: Smooth, rich, creamy character.  Emphasizes big malt flavor and clean finish.  Full but smooth malt character.

name: Edinburgh Ale
best_for: Strong Scottish style ales,  ESB, Irish Reds
notes: Malty strong ale yeast.  Reproduces complex, malty, flavorful schottish ales.  Hop character comes through well.

name: Edme Ale Yeast
best_for: Ales requiring high attenuation.
notes: Quick starting dry yeast with a good reputation. Produces some fruity ester. Highly attentive, so it will likely produce a slightly dry taste.

name: English Ale
best_for: English Pale Ale, ESB, India Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Porter, Sweet Stouts and Strong Ales
notes: Classic ESB strain best for English style milds, bitters, porters and English style stouts.  Leaves a clear beer with some residual sweetness.

name: English Cider Yeast
best_for: Cider, Wine and High Gravity Beer
notes: Classic Cider yeast.  Ferments dry, but retains apple flavor.  Some sulfer produced during fermentation will fade with age.

name: Essex Ale Yeast
best_for: British milds, pale ales, bitters, stouts.
notes: Flavorful British yeast with a drier finish than many ale yeasts.  Bready and fruity in character.  Well suited for top cropping (collecting).  Does not flocculate as much as WLP005 or WLP002.

name: European Ale
best_for: Alt, Kolsch, malty English Ales, Fruit beers
notes: Malty, Northern European ale yeast.  Low ester production, low sulfer, gives a clean profile.  Low attenuation contributes to malty taste.

name: European Ale Yeast
best_for: European Ales, German Ales, Alts, Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Kolsch
notes: Very malty flavor characteristic of Bavarian/Munich Ales.  Complex character.

name: European Lager II
best_for: Bohemian Pilsner, American Pilsner, Helles, Dunkel
notes: Clean, dry flavor profile for aggressively hopped pilsners.  Dry finish, mild aroma, slight sulfur production.

name: Forbidden Fruit
best_for: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru
notes: Phenolic profile with subdued fruitiness.  Available seasonally.

name: GF All American Ale
best_for: American Amber, Brown, IPA, Pale ales and stouts.  Blondes and fruit beers.
notes: Popular all purpose American ale style now in a Gluten Free strain.  Produces beers that are nutty, clean with a slight tart finish.  Ferment warmer to accentuate hops and add fruitiness or ferment cold for clean light citrus character.

name: German Ale
best_for: German Ales, Alts, Kolsch, Dry Stout
notes: Crisp, dry finish with a mild flavor.

name: German Ale II
best_for: Kolsch, Alt and German Pale Ales
notes: Strong sulfer component will reduce with aging.  Clean flavor, but with more ester production than regular German Ale Yeast.

name: German Ale/Kolsch
best_for: Kolsch, Altbiers, Pale Ales, Blonde and Honey Ales
notes: Great for light beers.  Accentuates hop flavors.  Slight sulfer flavor will fade with age and leave a clean, lager like ale.

name: German Bock Lager
best_for: Bocks, Doppelbocks, Oktoberfest, Vienna, Helles, some American Pilsners
notes: Produces beer that has balanced malt and hop character.  From Southern Bavaria.

name: German Lager
best_for: German Marzen, Pilsner, Lagers, Oktoberfest beers.
notes: Very malty and clean.  One of the world's most popular lager yeasts.

name: German Weiss
best_for: Weiss, Weizen, other Southern German Wheat styles
notes: Milder than German Wheat #1, this strain still produces the desired clove and phenol character, but to a lesser degree.  Full, earthy character.

name: German Wheat BT
best_for: Weizen, Weizenbocks
notes: Top fermenting Weizenbier yeast.  Intensely spicy, clovey and phenolic.  High attenuation.

name: German Wheat
best_for: Bavarian Weizen
notes: Subtle flavor profile.  Sharp, fruity, crisp, sherry like flavor.

name: Hefeweizen Ale
best_for: German style wheat beers.  Weiss, Weizen, Hefeweizen
notes: Produces the banana and clove nose traditionally associated with German Wheat beers.  Also produces desired cloudy look.

name: Hefeweizen IV Ale
best_for: German style Hefeweizen
notes: Large clove and phenolic aroma, but with minimal banana flavor.  Citrus and apricot notes.  Crisp and drinkable, with some sulfur production.

name: Irish Ale Yeast
best_for: Irish Ales, Stouts, Porters, Browns, Reds and Pale Ale
notes: Excellent for Irish Stouts.  Produces slight hint of diacetyl balanced by a light fruitiness and a slightly dry crispness.

name: Irish Ale
best_for: Irish Dry Stouts, Porter, Scottish Ale, Brown Ale, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine
notes: Dry diacetyl, fruity flavor characteristic of stouts.  Full bodied, dry, clean flavor.

name: Irish Dry Stout
best_for: Dry Stouts
notes: Top fermenting yeast which leaves a recognizable slightly woody character to Dry Stouts.  Vinous almost lactic character that blends well with roast malts.  High attenuation.

name: Klassic Ale Yeast
best_for: Bitters, milds, porters stouts and scottish ale styles.
notes: Traditional English Ale style yeast.  Produces ester character, and allows hop flavor through.  Leaves a slightly sweet malt character in ales.

name: Kolsch
best_for: German Kolsch
notes: Produces mild sulfer flavor which smooths with time to a clean attenuated flavor.  Mineral and malt characters come through well.  Clean, lightly yeasty flavor and aroma in the finish.

name: Kolsch Yeast
best_for: Kolsch, European Ales
notes: Very malty flavor with mix of lager and ale character.  Crisp, clean finish.

name: Lactobacillus Delbrueckii
best_for: Belgian gueze, lambic, sour brown ales, and Berliner Weisse.
notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium.  Produces mild acidity and sourness found in many types of Belgian beers.  Always used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae and wild yeasts.

name: Lalvin - K1V-1116
best_for: Souvingnon Blanc, Chenin Blanc and Seyval.
notes: Used for white grape varieties.  Rapid starter with constant and complete fermentation. Capable of surviving difficult conditions such as low nutrient or high SO2 levels.  Has low volatile action.

name: Lalvin 71B-1122
best_for: Young wines such as nouveau, blush and sugar white. Fruit meads.
notes: Rapid starter with constant and complete fermentation. Ability to metabolize high amounts (20-40%) of malic acid. Partial metabolism of malic acid helps soften the wine.  May produce significant esters, making it a good choice for concentrates.

name: Lalvin D-47
best_for: White wines such as Chardonnay and Rose.  Also good for mead.
notes: Recommended for white variety wines such as Chardonnay and Rose as well as Mead.  Low foaming, quick fermenting, forming a compact lees at the end of fermentation.  Use yeast nutrients if making mead.  Saccharomyces Cerevisiae.

name: Lalvin EC-1118
best_for: All types of wine and also cider.
notes: Low production of foam, volatile acid and H2S.  Ferments over a wide temperature range. High alcohol tolerance, compact lees and good flocculation.  Relatively neutral flavor and aroma.

name: Lalvin RC 212 (Bourgovin)
best_for: Red wines.
notes: RC212 recommended for red variety wines and high gravity beers.  Alcohol tolerance in the 12-14% range.  Low foaming and moderate speed fermenting.  Saccharomyces Cerevisiae.

name: London
best_for: Well balanced British style ales.
notes: Produces a clean, well balanced ale.  Medium attenuation preserves some beer complexity.

name: London Ale
best_for: Classic British Pale Ales, Bitters and Stouts
notes: Dry, malty ale yeast.  Produces a complex, oak flavored ester character.  Hop bitterness comes through well.

name: London Ale Yeast
best_for: English Ales, Bitters, IPAs, Brown Ale
notes: Dry finish, bold, rich flavor, some fruit profile and a crisp finish.

name: London Ale III
best_for: British Ales, Bitters
notes: Light, fruity flavor.  Balanced flavor with hint of sweetness.

name: London ESB Ale
best_for: English Bitters, IPA, Brown Ales, Mild Ales
notes: Malty, balanced flavor.  Fruity, rich finish.  Excellent for cask conditioned ales and bitters.

name: Manchester
best_for: Complex, full bodied Porters, Stouts, Ales.
notes: Old english style ale yeast that produces a complex, woody, full bodied ale at warm temperature.  Medium attenuation.  Good dry yeast for many english styles.

name: Mexican Lager
best_for: Mexican style light and dark lagers.
notes: From Mexico City - produces a clean lager beer with a crisp finish.  Good for mexican style beers.

name: Munich Lager
best_for: Pilsners, Light Lagers, Dortmond/Export, Marzen/Oktoberfest, Dunkel
notes: Unique Pilsner strain.  Very smooth, well-rounded and full bodied.  Benefits from a diacetyl rest.

name: Munton Fison Ale
best_for: High attenuation yeast good for most ales.
notes: Quick starting dry yeast.  Produces some fuity esters.  High attenuation produces clean finish.

name: North American Lager
best_for: American Pilsner, California Common, Canadian Lager, Oktoberfest, Marzen
notes: American and Canadian lager yeast. Malty finish makes it suitable for Marzens/Oktoberfest as well.

name: Northern German Lager
best_for: German pilsners, Mexican and Canadian Lagers
notes: Clean, crisp, traditional lager character.  Strong fermenting and forgiving yeast.  Excellent general purpose lager yeast.

name: Northwest Ale
best_for: Oregon Ales, All American Ale styles
notes: Classic Northwest US ale yeast.  Slight fruit flavor, malty ale with good body and balance.

name: Noth-Eastern Micro Ale
best_for: American Ales, Reds, Ambers
notes: Malty, bready, yet clean malt character.  Leaves hops flavor and aroma intact.  Versitile yeast for many American styles.

name: Nottingham
best_for: Good neutral ale yeast.
notes: Dry strain is highly flocculant and has high attenuation.  Produces relatively few fruity esters for a dry yeast. Can be fermented at low temperature to produce lager-style beers.

name: Nottingham Ale Yeast
best_for: British ales, pale ales, ambers, porters and stouts.
notes: British style of ale yeast with a very dry finish and high attenuation.  Medium to low fruit and fusel alcohol production.  Good top fermenting yeast for cropping.

name: Nottingham Yeast
best_for: Ales
notes: High flocculation - settles quickly.  Very good reputation as a fast starter and quick fermenter.  Clean and only slightly fruity.  Some nutty flavor in bottled version.  Relatively high attenuation.

name: Octoberfest/Marzen Lager
best_for: Marzen, Oktoberfest, European Lagers, Bocks, Munich Helles
notes: Produces a malty, bock style beer.  Does not finish as dry or as fast as White's German Lager yeast.  Longer lagering or starter recommended.

name: Old Bavarian Lager
best_for: German lagers, Bock, Dunkel, Helles
notes: Well rounded, malty with a subtle ester complex and citrus flavors.  Distinct, flavorful yeast is great for Southern German lager styles.

name: Old Bavarian Lager
best_for: Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bock and Dark Lagers.
notes: Southern Germany/Bavarian lager yeast.  Finishes malty with a slight ester profile.

name: Old German Ale
best_for: Altbier, German ales, some Wheat beers.
notes: Traditional Alt Bier flavor.  Strong fermenter with a smooth, attenuated, mild flavor.  Slightly dry, clean, quenching finish.

name: Original Pilsner
best_for: Classic Czech Pilsners
notes: Full bodied lager yeast with sweet, underattenuated finish.  Subdued diacetyl character.  Big malty palatte.  Classic Pilsner finish and style.

name: Pacific Ale
best_for: English & American ales including milds, bitters, IPA, porters and English stouts.
notes: Popular yeast from the Pacific Northwest.  Leaves a clear and malty profile.  More fruity than WLP002.  Suitable for many English and American styles.

name: Pasteur Champagne
best_for: Meads, Barleywines, Imperial Stouts and high gravity ales.
notes: High attenuation dry yeast. Good reputation.  Good for Meads and other high gravity ales.

name: Pediococcus Cerevisiae
best_for: Gueze and other Belgian styles.
notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium.  Creates a high level of lactic acidity over a long time.  Often used with other yeasts, and it may take several months for flavor to fully develop.

name: Pediococcus Damnosus
best_for: Belgian Lambic beers
notes: Slow growing bacteria used in secondary to create lactic acid flavor in Belgian lambics.  Produces large amounts of lactic acid and diacytl.  Prefers anaerobic conditions.

name: Pilsen Lager
best_for: American Pilsner, Bohemian Pilsner, Light Lagers
notes: Classic American pilsner strain.  Smooth with a malty flavor.  Dry and crisp fermentation.

name: Pilsner Lager
best_for: European Pilsners, Bohemian Pilsner
notes: Classic pilsner strain from Czech Republic.  Dry with a malty finish.

name: Premium Bitter Ale
best_for: All English ales including bitters, milds, ESB, Porter, Stout and Barley Wine
notes: From Staffordshire England.  Mild, but complex estery flavor.  High attenuation - ferments strong and dry.  Suitable for high gravity beers.

name: Ringwood Ale
best_for: Ringwood Ale, Brown Ales
notes: European ale yeast.  Highly flocculant with complex, clear, but malty profile.  Slightly fruity ester.

name: Roselare Belgian Blend
best_for: Belgian sour brown and red beers.
notes: Culture of Saccharomyces, Brettonomyces and Lactic Acid Bacteria.  Complex aromas and flavors.  May be used for primary fermentation.  Primarily for sour brown and red Belgian styles.

name: SafAle English Ale
best_for: Great general purpose ale yeast.
notes: Fast starting, fast fermenting yeast.  Quick attenuation helps to produce a clean, crisp, clear ale.  Can be used in a wide range of ales.

name: SafAle German Ale
best_for: High attenuation ales, wheat beers and weizens.
notes: Low sedimentation yeast, sometimes used in open fermentation. Good for wheat beers, weizens and light ales.

name: SafBrew Ale
best_for: Most ales.
notes: General purpose ale yeast, widely used.  Very consistent, clean finish. High attenuation and good flavor profile.

name: SafBrew Specialty Ale
best_for: Complex ales.
notes: Estery, somewhat spicy ale yeast. Solid yeast formation at end of fermentation.  Widely used for bottle and cask conditioning.

name: SafLager German Lager
best_for: Wide range of lagers and pilsners.
notes: Popular lager yeast strain.  Produces wide range of continental lagers and pilsners.  Clean finish.

name: SafLager West European Lager
best_for: German style Lagers and Pilsners.
notes: German lager yeast strain.  Performs well at low temperature. High flocculation and attenuation for a clean German finish.

name: Saison
best_for: French or Belgian Ales and Grand Cru styles.
notes: Pleasant yeast blend.  Leaves a smooth full character to the malt with mild, but pleasant esters and some apple pie spices.

name: San Francisco Lager
best_for: California and Premium Lagers, all American Lagers
notes: Produces "California Common" style beer.

name: Scottish Ale
best_for: Scottish Ale, Scottish Strong Ales, Sweet Stout, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine
notes: High alcohol tolerance.

name: Southern German Lager
best_for: German Pilsner, Helles, Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bocks
notes: Malty finish and balanced aroma.  Strong fermenter, slight sulfur and low diacetyl.

name: Southwold Ale
best_for: British bitters and pale ales.
notes: From Suffolk county.  Products complex fruity and citrus flavors.  Slight sulfer production, but this will fade with ageing.

name: Special Ale
best_for: All-malt beers.
notes: Highly attentive, clean finish dry yeast.

name: Steinberg-Geisenheim Wine
best_for: Riesling wines.
notes: German origin wine yeast.  High fruit/ester production.  Moderate fermentation characteristics and cold tolerant.

name: Super High Gravity Ale
best_for: Very high gravity beers and barley wine up to 25% alcohol.
notes: Ferments up to 25% alcohol content.  Flavor may vary greatly depending on beer alcohol.  English like esters at low gravity, but will become more wine-like as alcohol exceeds 16% ABV.  Refer to White Labs web page for tips on fermenting high gravity ales.

name: Sweet Mead/Wine
best_for: Sweet Mead, Wine and Cider
notes: Lower attenuation than White Labs Champagne Yeast.  Leaves some residual sweetness as well as fruity flavor.  Alcohol concentration up to 15%.

name: Thames Valley Ale
best_for: British Bitters, ESB, India Pale Ale, English Strong Ale
notes: Clean, complex flavor.  Low in fruit, low in esters, rich in flavor.  Hops come through well.

name: Trappist Ale
best_for: Trappist Ale, Dubbel, Trippel, Belgian Ales
notes: Distinctive fruitiness and plum characteristics.  Excellent for high gravity beers.

name: Trappist High Gravity
best_for: Belgian Wit, Trappist Ale, High gravity ales
notes: Robust top cropping yeast.  Phenolic character and alcohol tolerance up to 12%.  Rich ester profile and malty flavor.

name: Urquell Lager
best_for: Bohemian Pilsner
notes: Pilsner Urquell yeast with mild fruit/floral aroma.  Very dry and clean on palate with full mouth feel.  Subtle malt character.  Clean and neutral finish.

name: Weihenstephan Weizen
best_for: Bavarian Weizen
notes: Unique Bavarian wheat yeast that produces the spicy weizen clove and banana flavor.  Best when fermented at around 68 deg F.

name: Whitbread Ale
best_for: Whitbread Ale, British Ales, Pales, Bitters
notes: Slightly more fruity and malty than Wyeast's British Ale.  Clear and highly flocculant.

name: London ESB English Style Ale Yeast
best_for: Ales
notes: London ESB is a true English ale strain selected for reliable fermentation performance and moderate ester production that lets the flavors and aromas of malt and hops shine through. London ESB was selected from the Lallemand yeast culture library, and is an excellent choice  not only for brewing Extra Special Bitter but for other authentic heritage UK styles like Pale Ale, Bitter and Mild.  London ESB may also be used in the production of Ciders.

name: Wyeast Ale Blend
best_for: American and British Ale Styles.
notes: Blend of ale strains designed to provide quick starts, good flavor, balance and flocculation.  Balanced finish suitable for most American and British ale styles.

name: Wyeast Lager Blend
best_for: Classic Pilsners, Lagers, Bocks.
notes: Blend of lager strains to produce a complex but clean lager flavor profile.  Suitable for many common lager styles.

name: Zurich Lager
best_for: Swiss style lager, and high gravity lagers (over 11% ABV)
notes: Swiss style lager yeast.  Sulfer and diacytl production is minimal.  May be used for high gravity lagers with proper care.

name: Abbey IV Ale Yeast
best_for: Trappist Belgian Ales, Dubbels, Tripels and Specialty ales
notes: An authentic Trappist style ale yeast.  Use for Belgian ales including abbey ales (dubbels, tripels).  Fruit character is medium - between WLP500 (high) and WLP530 (low)

name: American Ale Yeast Blend
best_for: American ales with clean finish
notes: A blend that celebrates WLP001 (California Ale Yeast's) clean, neutral fermentation.  This strain is versatile and adds two other yeast strains that are also clean/neutral in flavor to add a bit of complexity - almost a lager like finish.  Slight sulfur m

name: American Farmhouse Blend
best_for: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales
notes: Inspired by local American brewers crafting semi-  traditional Belgian-style ales. This blend creates a complex flavor profile with a moderate level of sourness. It consists of a traditional farmhouse yeast strain and Brettanomyces. Great yeast for farmho

name: Antwerp Ale Yeast
best_for: Belgian pale and amber ales
notes: Clean, almost lager like Belgian ale yeast.  Good for Belgian pale and amber ales or with other Belgian yeasts in a blend.  Biscuity, ale like aroma present.  Hop flavors are accentuated.  Slight sulfur during fermentation, and a lager like flavor profile

name: Assmanshausen Wine Yeast
best_for: Pinot Noir and Zinfandel
notes: German red wine yeast, which results in spicy, fruit aromas. Perfect for Pinot Noir and Zinfandel. Slow to moderate fermenter which is cold tolerant.  Alcohol Tolerance: 16%

name: Australian Ale
best_for: Australian styles
notes: Produces a malty, bready, nutty character with a pleasant honey like finish. This yeast emphasizes malt nuances and is very forgiving in warmer fermentations for those who cannot ferment under controlled conditions.

name: Avize Wine Yeast
best_for: Chardonnay
notes: Champagne isolate used for complexity in whites. Contributes elegance, especially in barrel fermented Chardonnays.  Alcohol tolerance to 15%.

name: Belgian Lager Yeast
best_for: European style pilsners, dark  lagers, Vienna lager, and American style lagers
notes: Clean, crisp European lager yeast with low sulfur  production. The strain originates from a very old brewery in West Belgium.  Great for European style pilsners, dark  lagers, Vienna lager, and American style lagers.

name: Belgian Saison II Yeast
best_for: Belgian or French Saison
notes: Saison strain with a more fruity ester profile than WLP565 (Belgian Saison I Yeast).  Moderately phenolic with a clove-like characteristic in finished beer flavor and aroma.  Ferments quickly.

name: Belgian Sour Mix 1
best_for: Belgian sour beers (in secondary)
notes: Note: Bacteria to use in secondary only.  A unique blend perfect for Belgian style beers. Includes Brettanomyces, Saccharomyces, and the bacterial strains Lactobacillus and Pediococcus.

name: Belgian Strong Ale Yeast
best_for: Belgian dark strongs, Abbey ales and Christmas beers
notes: From the Ardennes region of Belgium, this classic strain produces moderate esters and spicy phenolic character.  Results in a dry but balanced finish.  Use for dark or strong abbey ales.

name: Belgian Style Saison Ale Yeast Blend
best_for: Belgian and French Saison
notes: This blend melds Belgian style ale and Saison strains. The strains work in harmony to create complex, fruity aromas and flavors. The blend of yeast strains encourages complete fermentation in a timely manner. Phenolic, spicy, earthy, and clove like flavor

name: Berliner Weisse Blend
best_for: Berliner Weisse
notes: A blend of a traditional German Weizen yeast and  Lactobacillus to create a subtle, tart, drinkable beer. Can  take several months to develop tart character.  Perfect for traditional Berliner Weisse.

name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
best_for: Belgian sour ales and labics (in secondary)
notes: Medium intensity Brett character. Classic strain used in secondary fermentation for Belgian style beers and lambics. One Trappist brewery uses this strain in secondary fermentation.

name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
best_for: Gueuze, Lambics and Sour Browns
notes: This strain of wild yeast was isolated from brewery cultures in the Brussels region of Belgium. It produces the classic sweaty horse blanket character and may form a pellicle in bottles or casks. The strain is generally used in conjunction with S. cerevis

name: Brettanomyces Claussenii
best_for: Sour ales (in secondary)
notes: Low intensity Brett character. Originally isolated from strong English stock beer, in the early 20th century. The Brett flavors produced are more subtle than WLP650 and WLP653. More aroma than flavor contribution. Fruity, pineapple like aroma.

name: Brettanomyces Lambicus
best_for: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales
notes: Use in secondary.  High intensity Brett character. Defines the "Brett character": Horsey, smoky and spicy flavors. As the name suggests, this strain is found most often in Lambic style beers, which are spontaneously fermented beers.

name: Brettanomyces Lambucus
best_for: Lambic
notes: This is a wild yeast strain isolated from Belgian lambic beers. It produces a pie cherry-like flavor and sourness with a distinct Brett character. A pellicle may form in bottles or casks. This strain works best in conjunction with other yeast and lactic b

name: Cabernet Red Wine Yeast
best_for: Merlot, Chardonnay, Chianti, Chenin Blanc, and Sauvignon Blanc
notes: High temperature tolerance. Moderate fermentation speed. Excellent for full-bodied red wines, ester production complements flavor. WLP760 is also suitable for Merlot, Chardonnay, Chianti, Chenin Blanc, and Sauvignon Blanc. Alcohol Tolerance: 16%

name: California Pub Ale
best_for: California and other American ales
notes: For that classic U.S. small brewery flavor. CL-50 produces terrific American red & pale ale styles. While attenuation is normal, this yeast produces a big, soft, well rounded malt flavor that really lets caramel malt flavors shine.

name: Chardonnay White Wine Yeast
best_for: Chardonnay Wine
notes: Dry wine yeast. Slight ester production, low sulfur dioxide production. Enhances varietal character. WLP730 is a good choice for all white and blush wines, including Chablis, Chenin Blanc, Semillon, and Sauvignon Blanc. Fermentation speed is moderate.  Al

name: Cream Ale Yeast Blend
best_for: Cream Ale, Hybrids
notes: A blend of ale and lager yeast strains that work together to create a clean, light American lager style ale.  A pleasing estery aroma may be perceived.  Hop flavors and bitterness are slightly subdued.  Slight sulfer will be produced during fermentation f

name: Flor Sherry Yeast
best_for: Sherry wine yeast
notes: This yeast develops a film (flor) on the surface of the wine. Creates   green almond, granny smith and nougat characteristics found in sherry. Can also be used for Port, Madeira and other sweet styles. For use in secondary fermentation. Slow fermentor. Al

name: French Red Wine Yeast
best_for: Bordeaux
notes: Classic Bordeaux yeast for red wine fermentations. Moderate fermentation characteristics. Tolerates lower fermentation temperatures. Rich, smooth flavor profile.  Alcohol Tolerance: 17%

name: French Saison
best_for: French and Belgian Saison or Farmhouse ales
notes: A very versatile strain that produces Saison or farmhouse style biers as well as other Belgian style beers that are highly aromatic (estery), peppery, spicy and citrusy. This strain enhances the use of spices and aroma hops, and is extremely attenuative b

name: French White Wine Yeast
best_for: French white wines
notes: Classic yeast for white wine fermentation. Slow to moderate fermenter and foam producer. Gives an enhanced creamy texture.  Alcohol Tolerance: 16%

name: Lactobacillus
best_for: Belgian sout beers (secondary)
notes: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from a Belgian brewery. This culture produces moderate levels of acidity and is commonly found in many types of beers including gueuze, lambics, sour brown ales and Berliner Weisse. It is always used in conjunction with S.cer

name: Lactobacillus Bacteria
best_for: Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze (secondary)
notes: Bacteria for use in secondary.  This lactic acid bacteria produces moderate levels of acidity and sour flavors found in lambics, Berliner Weiss, sour brown ale and gueze.

name: Malolactic Bacteria
best_for: Primarily wine
notes: Bacteria for use in secondary.  Malolactic fermentation is the conversion of malic acid to lactic acid by bacteria from the lactic acid bacteria family.  Lactic acid is less acidic than malic acid, which in turn decreases acidity and helps to soften and/o

name: Manchester Ale Yeast
best_for: English style ales
notes: Top fermenting strain that is good for top-cropping.  Moderately flocculent with a clean, dry finish.  Low ester profile for producing a balanced English ale.

name: Merlot Red Wine Yeast
best_for: Merlot, Shiraz, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Cabernet, Sauvignon Blanc, and Semillon
notes: Neutral, low fusel alcohol production. Will ferment to dryness, alcohol tolerance to 18%. Vigorous fermenter. WLP740 is well suited for Merlot, Shiraz, Pinot Noir, Chardonnay, Cabernet, Sauvignon Blanc, and Semillon.  Alcohol Tolerance: 18%

name: Octoberfest Lager Blend
best_for: Octoberfest, Marzen, Bavarian lagers
notes: This blend of lager strains is designed to produce a rich, malty, complex and full bodied Octoberfest style beer. It attenuates well while leaving plenty of malt character and mouthfeel. This strain is low in sulfur production.

name: Pediococcus
best_for: Belgian sour ales
notes: Lactic acid bacteria used in the production of Belgian style beers where additional acidity is desirable. Often found in gueuze and other Belgian style beer. Acid production will increase with storage time. It may also cause ropiness and produce low level

name: Sake Yeast
best_for: Sake wine yeast
notes: For use in rice based fermentations. For sake, use this yeast in conjunction with Koji (to produce fermentable sugar). WLP705 produces full body sake character, and subtle fragrance.  Alcohol tolerance to 16%.

name: Scottish Ale
best_for: Scottish ales
notes: Use for classic Scottish heavys, 90's- or strong ales. This yeast produces a soft, fruity malt profile with a subtle woody, oakey ester profile. A mild, mineral like dryness in the finish makes this a very complex strain.

name: Suremain Burgundy Wine Yeast
best_for: Burgundy
notes: Emphasizes fruit aromas in barrel fermentations. High nutrient requirement to avoid volatile acidity production. Alcohol Tolerance: 16%

name: Swiss Lager
best_for: European pilsners and lagers
notes: A unique strain that has both a clean, crisp lager flavor and a soft, smooth maltiness. Perfect for European Pilsners. Like our CL-660 strain, this is an excellent all purpose Lager yeast for those wanting a fuller, rounder palate.

name: Yorkshire Square Ale Yeast
best_for: English pale ales, English brown ales and Mild ales
notes: This yeast produces a malty but well balanced profile.  Expect toasty flavors with malt driven esters.  Highly flocculent and a good choice for many English ales.

name: Blanche Ale Yeast
best_for: Wheat beer, Wit
notes: Top fermenting strain for Belgian witbier and wheats.  Spicy and lightly phenolic.

name: Diamond Lager
best_for: Lagers
notes: Diamond Lager yeast originated in Germany and is used in a number of commercial breweries to produce various lagers.

name: Lager Yeast
best_for: Lagers
notes: A dry lager yeast with high attenuation.  Ferments clean and malty.

name: Munuch
best_for: Wheat beers
notes: Danstar Munich Wheat Beer yeast originated in Bavaria, Germany, the home of many of the world’s great wheat beer breweries.

name: Safale American
best_for: American ale, other clean finish ales
notes: American ale yeast that produces well balanced beers with low diacetyl and a very clean, crisp end palate.

name: Safbrew Wheat
best_for: Wheat beers
notes: A specialty yeast for wheat beer fermentation.  The yeast produces a subtle estery and phenlol flavor typical of wheat beers.

name: Saflager Lager
best_for: European lagers
notes: A famous yeast strain from Weihenstephan Germany used worldwide in brewing.  Their most popular strain for lagers.

name: Denny's Favorite
best_for: American Ambers, Browns, IPAs, Scotch Ale, Brown Porter, Cream Ale, Fruit Beer, Red Ale
notes: This terrific all-round yeast can be used for almost any beer style, and is a mainstay of one of our local homebrewers, Mr. Denny Conn. It is unique in that it produces a big mouthfeel and accentuates the malt, caramel, or fruit character of a beer without being sweet or under-attenuated.

name: West Yorkshire Ale
best_for: English IPA, Bitters, Stouts, Browns
notes: This strain produces ales with a full chewy malt flavor and character, but finishes dry, producing famously balanced beers. Expect moderate nutty and stone-fruit esters. Best used for the production of cask-conditioned bitters, ESB and mild ales. Reliably flocculent, producing bright beer without filtration.

name: Biere de Garde
best_for: Biere de Garde, Saison, Belgian Blonde, Belgian Pale Ale, Belgian Golden Strong
notes: Low to moderate ester production with subtle spiciness. Malty and full on the palate with initial sweetness. Finishes dry and slightly tart. Ferments well with no sluggishness.

name: Belgian Dark Ale
best_for: Belgian Strong Dark and Golden Ales, Belgian Quadrupel, Oud Bruin/Flanders Brown, Fruit Beers, Belgian Specialty Beers
notes: This unique Belgian ale yeast is a high acid producer with balanced ester and phenol production allowing a good expression of malt profile, especially the strong flavors of darker malts and sugars. High alcohol tolerance. Spicy, tart, and dry on the palate with a very complex finish.

name: Scotch Whisky Yeast
best_for: Scotch Whiskey Yeast
notes: A strain that was widely used for Scotch Whisky production from the early 1950s, producing a complex array of ester compounds and fusel oils, as well as some spicy, clove character. Suitable for Scotch Whisky or American-style Whiskey. Used in high-gravity beers.

name: Tennessee Whisky Yeast
best_for: American Whisky
notes: Suitable for American-style whiskey and bourbon. This yeast is famous for creating rich, smooth flavors. Clean and dry fermenting yeast. Will tolerate high alcohol concentrations (15%), and ester production is low. Also popular in high-gravity beers.

name: American Whisky Yeast
best_for: Bourbon or American Whisky
notes: Yeast strain that produces low ester profile and moderate fusel oils. Temperature and alcohol tolerant and suitable for American-style whiskey using barley or corn base. Also used in high-gravity beers.

name: Bourbon Whisky Yeast
best_for: Bourbon Whisky
notes: From a tradtional distillery in the heart of Bourbon country, this strain produces a carmel, malty character with balanced ester profile. Suitable for Bourbon or other American Whiskey with barley, rye, or corn as the base grain. Used in high-gravity beers.

name: French Ale
best_for: Biere de Garde, Blonde, Brown Ales and Specialty Beers
notes: Clean strain that complements malt flavor. Low to moderate esters, when fermentation temperature is below 70°F.  Moderate plus ester character over 70°F.  Low diacetyl production. Good yeast strain for Biere de Garde, blond, amber, brown ales, and specialty beers.

name: Old Sonoma
best_for: American Ales, Porters, Stouts
notes: Yeast from an historic brewery in Northern California, this strain was embraced by the early pioneers of craft beer in America and continues to be a great choice for those seeking to use a traditional British-style yeast. A neutral and versatile strain, it is a great choice for pale ales, porters, and stouts.

name: Neutral Grain Yeast
best_for: High gravity beers
notes: Marked by a clean, fast fermentation, this strain is ideal for any neutral grain spirit. Alcohol and temperature tolerant. Used in high-gravity beers.

name: English Ale Blend
best_for: English Pale Ale, Stouts, Bitters, Porters and India Pale Ale
notes: A blend of British ale yeast strains, designed to add complexity to your ale. Moderate fruitiness and mineral-like, with little to no sulfur. Drier than WLP002 and WLP005, but with similar flocculation properties. Good yeast blend for English Pale Ale, Bitter, Porter, Stout, and India Pale Ale.

name: San Diego Super Yeast
best_for: A wide variety of styles requiring clean, fast fermentation and finish
notes: A super clean, super-fast fermenting strain. A low ester-producing strain that results in a balanced, neutral flavor and aroma profile. Alcohol-tolerant and very versatile for a wide variety of styles. Similar to California Ale Yeast WLP001 but it generally ferments faster.

name: Belgian Saison III Yeast
best_for: Saison, Summer Ales, Farmhouse Ales
notes: Produces beer with a high fruit ester characteristic, as well as some slight tartness. Finishes slightly malty, which balances out the esters. Also produces low levels of clovey phenolics. Great yeast choice for a summer Saison that is light and easy-drinking.

name: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis Trois
best_for: Sour beers, Belgian Sour Variations
notes: This Belgian strain, used traditionally for 100% Brettanomyces fermentations, produces a slightly tart beer with delicate characteristics of mango and pineapple. Can also be used to produce effervescence when bottle-conditioning.

name: Flemish Ale Blend
best_for: Flemish Ale, Sour Ales
notes: Blended culture used to produce the classic beer styles of the West Flanders region of Belgium . A proprietary blend of Saccharomyces yeasts, Brettanomyces, Lactobacillus, and Pediococcus, this culture creates a more complex, dark stone fruit characteristic than WLP 655 Belgian Sour Mix

name: California Pinot Noir Yeast
best_for: Pinot Noir Wine Yeast
notes: Isolated from Pinot Noir grapes by White Labs in Davis, CA. This strain produces fruity and complex aromas, and is an ideal choice for hardy red wine varieties, as well as aromatic white wines such as Chardonnay. This strain is reliable for difficult fermentations.

name: Sake #9 Yeast
best_for: Sake and rice based wines
notes: For use in rice-based fermentations. Traditional strain used in Ginjo-shu production because of the yeast’s development of high fragrance components. Also a fairly strong fermenter, but producing a foamless fermentation.

name: Munich Helles Yeast
best_for: A variety of lager styles including Helles, Rauchbier and Munich Lagers
notes: This yeast helps to produce a malty, but balanced traditional Munich-style lager. Clean and strong fermenter, it's great for a variety of lager styles ranging from Helles to Rauchbier.

name: Whitbread Ale Yeast
best_for: English style ales, milds, bitters, porters, and English ales as well as some North Amreican ales
notes: Traditional mixed yeast culture. British style character, slightly fruity, with a hint of sulfur production. This yeast can be used for many different beer styles. The most traditional choices would be English style ales including milds, bitters, porters, and English style stouts. North American style ales will also benefit from fermentation with WLP017. The beer will clear easily.

name: Abbaye Belgian
best_for: Belgian Ales
notes: Complex aroma and flavors may include peppery, fruity, banana, clovy, alcoholic, sweet and fruity. Does not display undesirable odors when properly handled.

name: Belle Saison
best_for: Saison, Bière de Garde, Belgian style beers
notes: Belle Saison produces esters and phenols, which results in beers with fruity, peppery and spicy flavors and aromas. Belle Saison is suitable for primary fermentation for beers up to 14% ABV. The yeast would require extra nutrition above that level of alcohol such as an addition of 1g/hL of Servomyces.

name: CBC-1
best_for: CBC-1 can be used to referment any type of ale. Used for cask and bottle conditioning.
notes: CBC-1 is suitable for primary fermentation for fruit beers and Champagne-like beers up to 12% ABV. Neutral flavor and aroma. Alcohol resistant. Not able to utilize maltotriose.

name: Dry Belgian Ale
best_for: Belgian ales
notes: Dry Belgian Ale is single strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae isolated from a unique golden strong ale. The profile is a complex and balanced mix of apple, pear and light citrus fruit with some mild spicy and peppery notes. The apparent attenuation of this strain ranges anywhere from 85-100%, depending upon the mash profile and the grist composition.For a yeast that's as dry as it is, it creates beers with a surprising amount of balance even without the use of specialty grains or adjuncts. While we haven't completed our own tests in house, this yeast is used at the brewery from which it was isolated to make big beers that are in the neighborhood of 12-16% ABV and sufficiently dry. Use Dry Belgian Ale as a primary fermenter in any big Belgian beer, or to unstick that pesky stuck fermentation.

name: Franconian Dark Lager
best_for: Dark Lagers
notes: Franconian Dark Lager is a single strain of Saccharomyces pastorianus that hails from the Franconia region of Germany. This yeast exhibits a short lag time and has flavor profile characteristics that complement dark, roasted malts. The dark malt complementing nature of this yeast makes it a perfect fit for any big, malt driven dark lagers.We recommend a brief diacetyl rest at ~ 60-65 ºF (2-3 days) at the end of primary fermentation. An extended lagering phase at 33-35 ºF will encourage the yeast to settle and create a clean profile.

name: Hessian Pils
best_for: Pilsner
notes: Hessian Pils is a single strain of Saccharomyces pastorianus that hails from the Hess region of Germany. It exhibits everything you want in a great Pilsner yeast: it's a clean fermenter with relatively low ester formation, exhibits a short lag time, ferments wort quickly and attenuates well, even at the low end of the temperature range. These characteristics allow the malt and hop profile to really shine, and creates a crisp finished beer.We recommend a brief diacetyl rest at ~ 60-65 ºF (2-3 days) at the end of primary fermentation. An extended lagering phase at 33-35 ºF will encourage the yeast to settle and create a clean profile.

name: Midwestern Ale
best_for: Porter, stout, brown, amber, IPA, pale ale, or American wheat beer
notes: Midwestern Ale yeast is a single strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae isolated from a storied brewery in the heartland of America, well suited for fermentation of a broad spectrum of worts.A relatively fast fermenter with good attenuation and pleasant ester profile that can be tuned via the fermentation temperature, this yeast is great for any porter, stout, brown, amber, IPA, pale ale, or American wheat beer.Expect this yeast to ferment cleaner with a low ester profile at the cooler fermentation temperatures, and produce a more pronounced ester profile at warmer fermentation temperatures

name: Munton Fison Premium
best_for: English ale
notes: This yeast produces relatively high ester formation with a low residual sweetness but is also very robust.

name: Northeastern Abbey
best_for: Wit, Belgian ale
notes: This yeast was isolated from a beer crafted by a well-known producer of Belgian-style ales in the Northeastern United States. This yeast produces a very mild spiciness and earthy flavor and aroma which is complemented by a subtle but magnificent array of fruity esters, including pear and light citrus fruit.The brewery from which this strain was isolated uses it in a very versatile manner across an array of Belgian styles. We prefer using this yeast for any and all light Belgian beers, including Wit, Belgian Pale and Belgian Blond, in addition to any experimental fruit beers in which a more unique and robust flavor and aroma profile is desired. Expect this yeast to produce a large, thick krausen.

name: Saison Blend
best_for: Saison
notes: A blend of two unique yeast strains isolated from beers that embody the saison style, this blend is a balance of the many characteristic saison flavors and aromas. One yeast strain is a good attenuator that produces a spicy and mildly tart and tangy beer with a full mouthfeel. The other yeast strain is also a good attenuator that produces a delightful ester profile of grapefruit and orange zest and imparts a long, dry and earthy finish to the beer. Together, they produce a dry but balanced beer with a unique flavor and aroma profile.

name: Saison Blend II
best_for: Saison, Farmhouse ale
notes: This saison blend is the Saccharomyces portion of our Farmhouse Sour Ale, available to you as a result of popular demand from the commercial brewing crowd. This combination of Saccharomyces strains embodies the balanced fusion of the two foremost saison flavor/aroma characters, fruitiness and earthiness.Each Saccharomyces strain in this blend produces flavor compounds that serve as the yin to the other's yang, and the result is an exceptionally complex yet balanced flavor and aroma profile. One strain will serve to create an ester profile of grapefruit and orange zest, while the other will produce a mild earthiness and spiciness.

name: Top
best_for: American IPA, Dark ales, Witbier
notes: Top fermenting yeast that most suitable for amber coloured and dark beers. Fast fermentation with low residual sugar. Formation of fruity esters.

name: Vermont Ale
best_for: IPA
notes: Isolated from a uniquely crafted double IPA out of the Northeastern United States, this yeast produces a balanced fruity ester profile of peaches and light citrus that complements any aggressively hopped beer. Expect this strain to take off fast and ferment wort quickly, though elevating the temperature following the bulk of fermentation may be required to raise the attenuation.In order to achieve high attenuation, we recommend fermenting at 64-68 ºF for 5-7 days, and then raising the temperature to 70 ºF until a stable gravity is reached. We also recommend mashing at 148-149 ºF and adding a small percentage of the fermentables (~ 5-10%) as sugar.

name: Wallonian Farmhouse
best_for: Farmhouse ale, Belgian ale
notes: Isolated from a unique farmhouse-style ale that hails from the Walloon region of Belgium, this yeast is one of the funkiest "clean" yeast we have in our stable. It imparts a slight earthy funk and tart character to the beer, and is a very mild producer of some slightly spicy and mildly smokey flavor compounds.This yeast exhibits absurdly high attenuation, resulting in a practically bone-dry beer. If desired, we recommend controlling the dryness by adjusting the mash temperature or adding malts or adjuncts to the mash tun that will lend some body and residual sweetness to the beer.When fermented cool this yeast will provide a cleaner profile, and the character development will increase proportionally with increasing fermentation temperature.

name: West Coast IPA
best_for: American IPA, Imperial IPA, American Pale Ale, American brown ale, Red Ales, Scottish Ales
notes: Thorough attenuation, temp tolerance, and good flocculation make this an easy strain to work with. Flavor is balanced neutral with mild ester formation at warmer temps, allowing hops, character malts, and flavorings to show through.

name: English Special Bitter
best_for: Extra Special, Bitters
notes: Similar to 1968, slightly less flocculent. Produces light fruit ethanol aroma. Mild malt with a neutral soft finish. Very clean.

name: Dry Wine
best_for: Asti type, Brandy, Cabernet Franc,Cava type, Chardonnay, Cognac, Armagnac, Common Perry, Dolcetto, Dry Mead, Eau de Vie, French Cider, Grappa/Marc/Bagaceira, Melon (Muscadet), Muscat Blanc, Pinot Gris, Pinotage, Red ,Bordeaux type blends, Rum, Scotch, Sémillon, Seyval Blanc, Sherry, Soave type ,blends, Sparkling wine, Traditional Perry, Trebbiano/Ugni Blanc, Vermouth, Vodka, Whiskey
notes: Used in many white wine fermentations and also some red wines. Also used for secondary fermentation of barley wine. Ferments crisp and dry, ideal for base wines in making sparkling wine. Low foaming, excellent barrel fermentation, good flocculating characteristics.

name: Red Wine
best_for: Ideal for red or white wines, which mature rapidly with Beaujolais type fruitiness, and for bigger reds requiring aging. Low foaming, low sulfur production over a broad range of temperatures.

name: Sweet Mead
best_for: Common cider, sweet mead, Braggot
notes: Leaves 2-3% residual sugar in most meads. Rich, fruity profile complements fruit mead fermentations. Use of Vintner's Choice yeast nutrient is recommended.

name: Fruity White
best_for: Fruity wines
notes: Produces extremely fruity profile, high ester formation, bready aromas with vanilla notes. Allows fruit character to dominate aroma and flavor profile. Finishes slightly sweet and soft.

name: Italian Red
best_for: Chianti, Fruit cider, Apple wine
notes: Rich, very big and bold, well rounded profile. Nice soft fruit character with dry crisp finish. Excellent choice for most Italian grape varieties.

name: Summation Red
best_for: Cabernet, Malbec, Port, Sauvignon Blanc, Merlot
notes: Produces distinctive intense berry, graham cracker nose. Jammy, rich, very smooth complex profile, slightly vinous. Well suited to higher sugar content musts.

name: Extreme Fermentation
best_for: Brandy, Cognac, Rum, Scotch, Vodka
notes: A very good choice for alcohol tolerance and stuck fermentations. Produces a very clean, dry profile, low ester formation and other volatile aromatics.

name: Dry Mead
best_for: Braggot, Dry mead
notes: Best choice for dry mead. Used in many award winning meads. Low foaming with little or no sulfur production. Use additional nutrients for mead making.

name: Cider
best_for: Apple wine, Common cider, English cider
notes: Crisp and dry fermenting yeast with big, fruity finish. Creates a nice balance for all types of apples, pears, and other fruit. Allows fruit character to dominate the profile.

name: Dry / Fortified
best_for: Brandy, Chianti, Cognac, Merlot, Port, Zinfandel
notes: Mild toast and vanilla nose. Mild fruit profile with balanced depth and complexity. Very dry finish. Dry red and white wines, add brandy for classic ports. Also used for big red wines and high sugar musts.

name: Sweet White
best_for: Braggot, Cider, Dry Mead, Icewine, Fruit cider, Sweet mead, Vermouth
notes: Produces distinct Riesling character. Rich flavor, creamy, fruity profile with nice dry finish and a hint of Riesling sweetness in the aftertaste.

name: Bold Red
best_for: Apple wine, Cabernet Sauvignon, Dry Mead, Pinot Noir, Rum, Vodka
notes: Dominating, strong fermentation characteristics. Alcohol tolerant to 18% (v/v). Ideal for Zinfandel, Pinot Noir, Syrah, or any high sugar must. Good choice for restarting stuck fermentations.

name: Safebrew Abbey Ale
best_for: Abbey Ales
notes: Active dry yeast recommended to brew a diversity of beers amongst which abbey style beers known for their high alcohol content. It ferments very fast and reveals subtle and well-balanced aromas. To maintain the aromatic profile at the end of the fermentation crop the yeast as soon as possible after fermentation.

name: American West Coast Ale
best_for: American Barleywine, American Pale Ale, American Amber ale, American Brown ale, American IPA, American Wheat, blonde ale, Cream ale, Kölsch, Imperial IPA, Irish red ale, Extra Special bitter, Scottish ale, Strong Scottish ale, Strong ale
notes: BRY-97 is suitable for primary fermentation for beers up to 12% ABV. The yeast would require extra nutrition above that level of alcohol such as an addition of 1g/hL of Servomyces. Slightly estery, almost neutral.

name: Scottish Bitter
best_for: Scottish Ales
notes: CL-210 has a soft, yeasty, fruity nose which yields to a well attenuated malt flavor and big ester complex of ripe fruit, apricots and rose petals. Dry and complex, yet smooth and fruity with mild sulphur.

name: BugFarm
best_for: Lambic
notes: A mixed culture of wild yeast and lactic bacteria to emulate sour or wild beers such as lambic-style ales. Over time displays a citrus sourness and barnyard funk profile. Contains yeast (Saccharomyces, Brettanomyces) and lactic bacteria (Lactobacillus, Pediococcus). The "Brett" population is typically >50% of the culture pitch. The blend of strains change every calendar year for those who like to blend or have solera projects.

name: Flemish Ale
best_for: Flemish red, oud brune, sour beers
notes: A unique blend of yeast and lactic bacteria producing sour beers with leather, fruit, and cherry stone flavors. Perfect for Flemish reds, oud brune, other sour ales. The blend contains a base Belgian yeast, several Brettanomyces, Lactobacilli, and Pediococcus.

name: Farmhouse Blend
best_for: Saison
notes: A saison blend (ECY08) with a wild isolate from a small but fascinating producer of Saison. Can produce a funky and acidic farmhouse ale particularly when a secondary fermentable is added (i.e. priming sugar or fruit).

name: Brettanomyces Anomala
best_for: Lambics and Flanders/Sour Brown ales
notes: Originally identified by 26S rDNA partial sequencing and was isolated in beer from Adelaide, Australia. This species displays strong fruity esters, moderate barnyard and gradual acidity over time.  Name of Alternate State or Synonym: Dekkera anomala, Brettanomyces intermedius.

name: Berliner Blend
best_for: Berliner weisse, Gosebier, and other styles where lactic sourness is desired
notes: Designed to be pitched into primary fermentation for Berliner weisse, Gosebier, and other styles where lactic sourness is desired, the blend contains a kolsch yeast, Lactobacillus brevis and Lactobacillus delbreuckii. Suggested fermentation temperature: 70-74ºF.

name: Scottish Heavy
best_for: Heavy Ales, 90/ Shilling, Barley wine
notes: Leaves a fruity profile with woody, oak esters reminiscent of malt whiskey. Well suited for 90/ shilling or heavier ales including old ales and barleywines due to the level of attenuation (77-80%). Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-68F.

name: Saison Brasserie
best_for: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde
notes: A combination of several saison yeast strains for both fruity and spicy characteristics accompanied with dryness (attenuation ~ 80%). Suggested fermentation temperature: 75-85F.

name: Belgian Abbaye
best_for: Belgian style ales
notes: This yeast produces classic Belgian-style ales - robust, estery with a large note of clove and fruit. Rated highly in sensory tests described in "Brew Like a Monk" for complexity and low production of higher alcohols. Attenuation 74-76%, fermentation temperature 66-72F.

name: Ols Newark Ale
best_for: American ales, English ales
notes: Sourced from a defunct east coast brewery, this pure strain was identified as their "ale-pitching yeast". Good for all styles of American and English ales with high flocculation and a compact sedimentation. Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-68F; attenuation ~76%.

name: Belgian Abbaye 2
best_for: Belgian style ales
notes: Traditional Belgian yeast with a complex, dry, fruity malt profile. Rated highly in sensory tests described in "Brew Like a Monk" for complexity and low production of higher alcohols. Attenuation 74-76%; fermentation temperature: 66-72F.

name: Saison Single
best_for: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde
notes: This strain leaves a smooth, full farmhouse character with mild esters reminiscent of apple pie spice. Attenuation 76-78%; fermentation temperature: 75-82F.

name: Munich Festbier
best_for: Helles, Dunkel, Oktoberfest
notes: From one of the oldest breweries in Munich, this pure strain is recommended for many German lagers such as Helles, Dunkel, and Oktoberfest. Suggested fermentation temperature: 46-54F; medium attenuation.

name: Brettanomyces Nanus (Strain 2)
best_for: Sour beers
notes: Name of Alternate State or Synonym: Eeniella nana. ​This yeast was first isolated from bottled beer in Sweden.

name: Burton Union
best_for: English pale ales, ESB
notes: Produces a bold, citrusy character which accentuates mineral and hop flavors. Well suited for classic English pale ales and ESB.  Attenuation 73-75%; fermentation temperature: 64-69F.

name: BugCountry
best_for: Lambic, Sours
notes: With over 20 different isolates combined for fermentation to overwhelm the senses, this blend is the mother-bugger for wild ales. Like the BugFarm, Brettanomyces dominants the overall population, however, other wild yeast seen in spontaneous fermentations are also included (such as Pichia  and Kloeckera ).  Several strains of Saccharomyces, Lactobacillus and Pediococcus round out this large and complex culture.

name: Kolschbier
best_for: Kolsch
notes: Produces a clean lager-like profile at ale fermentation temperatures. Smooth mineral and malt flavors come through with a clean, lightly yeasty flavor and aroma in the finish. Recommended fermentation temperature: 58-66F; attenuation:75-78%.

name: Oud Brune
best_for: Sours
notes: For primary fermentations. A unique blend of fruity Belgian Saccharomyces yeast and Lactobacilli species (L. delbrueckii and L. brevis). For those who prefer sourness without the presence of Brett. Additional info: Suggested fermentation temperature: 68-74ºF

name: Kellerbier
best_for: Northern German Lagers, Pilsners
notes: This yeast exhibits a clean, crisp lager in the traditional northern German character. Use in German pilsners including Kellerbier. Recommended fermentation temperature: 46-54F; attenuation: 74-76%.

name: Brettanomyces Naardenensis
best_for: Lambic, Sour
notes: A unique species of Brettanomyces that creates an abundance of acidity quickly (some acetic acid likely) and may initially display a mousy-like tainted flavor but dissipates over time leading to ester production with hints of strawberry. Aging up to 6 months is recommended. Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-74 F.  Name of Alternate state or synonym: Dekkera naardenensis

name: Lactobacillus Brevis
best_for: Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze (secondary)
notes: This strain of L. brevis was originally isolated from kefir. Bright acidity and hop-tolerant. Fermnetation temperature 60 - 80 F.

name: Dirty Dozen Brett Blend
best_for: Lambic, Sour, Gueze
notes: Twelve (12) different isolates of atypical yeast exhibiting high production of barnyard "funk" and esters. Dryness, ripe fruit, and acidity will be encountered over a period of months and over time (>1 yr), may display gueuze-like qualities in complexity. Contains various isolates from lambic-producers, B. bruxellensis, B. anomala, B. lambicus, and B. naardenensis.  For those who want the most from "Brett" yeast, whether a 100% fermentation is desired or adding to secondary aging projects.  Suggested fermentation temperature: 60-74 F. Attenuation high.

name: Brussels Bruxellensis
best_for: Gueuze, Lambics and Sour Browns
notes: Produces classic Brett “Barnyard” characteristics plus some subtle fruity aroma and moderate acidity.  Adds a tart complexity to any beer.

name: Tart Cherry Brett
best_for: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns
notes: Produces some Brett Barnyard funk plus stone fruit and cherry-like esters.  This Strain also produces a moderate amount of acid that adds a tart complexity to the brew.This yeast is highly attenuative but tends to ferment about ½ as fast as a typical ale strain.  Although it attenuates faster than GB001, it is typically best used in combination with faster fermenting yeast in the primary or added to the secondary to add complexity while aging.

name: Fast Souring Lacto
best_for: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales
notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures.  You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables.  More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring.We recommend brewing with GB110 in one of three ways.  I)  “Hot Start”:  Pitch GB110 to wort at 98 F with little or no hops for 48-72 hrs.  Wort may be soured before kettle boil or after.  If soured before kettle boil,  boil with hop additions as usual.  If soured after kettle boil cool wort and pitch yeast.  II)  “Co-Pitch”:  Pitch GB110 into a primary with yeast of your choice at 68-72 F.  Wort that is less than 1050 and 7 IBU will typically be very sour in 2-3 weeks.    III)  “Secondary”:  Pitch GB110 after primary fermentation for an aged sour.  Souring by this method typically requires several months.  Adding simple sugars or fruit etc. will enhance souring in the secondary.

name: Farmhouse Sour
best_for: Saisons, Farmhouse Ales
notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.

name: Berliner Blend
best_for: Berliner Weisse
notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.

name: Sour Plum Belgian
best_for: Trapist Ales, Sours
notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.

name: Saison Sour
best_for: Saison, Lambic, Berliner Weiss, Sour Brown and Gueze
notes: Lactic Acid Bacteria are inhibited by hops, high gravity and low temperatures. You can adjust sourness by increasing or decreasing these variables. More than 7 IBU, gravity above 1050 or temps below 65 F will increase the time to sour or lead to reduced overall souring. Warmer fermentation temps will typically increase the esters and spicy phenolics of the saison ale yeast in this blend.

name: Sweet Flemish Brettt
best_for: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns
notes: Brew with GB144 on it’s own to make an all brett beer, in a primary fermentation with an ale yeast for a complex blended profile or in a secondary to add character during aging.

name: Sour Cherry Funk
best_for: Sours
notes: This blend creates an amazing complex, sour beer with fruity cherry esters.  Fermenting in the presence of 7-10 IBUs will cause the fermentation to complete much more quickly but will slow the souring —  expect to wait 3-4 months for significant souring.  Fermenting with zero or less than 5 IBUs will allow souring to happen much faster (within two weeks) but will cause the fermentation to take up to 4 weeks to complete.

name: Brux Blend
best_for: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns
notes: A blend of Brettanomyces yeast that produces stone fruit esters and a hint of barnyard. Creates a moderate amount of acid that adds a tart complexity to the brew.  This blend is highly attenuative if left for long periods of time but ferments more slowly than a typical ale yeast.  Use GB156 in a primary if fermented for 2-3 weeks or for conditioning a fermented beer during aging. This blend is highly attenuative but tends to ferment about ½ as fast as a typical ale strain

name: NorCal Ale One
best_for: Barley wine, Pale ale, Bitter, Scotch ale, IPA, Stout
notes: Clean Fermenting, versatile strain from one of the most famous California Pale Ales.  Neutral flavor profile creates a crisp beer and allows hops to shine.  Strong attenuator and good flocculation perfectly suited for a large variety of styles.  Good choice for high gravity beers.

name: Czech Pilsner
best_for: Pilsners, Lagers
notes: Bottom fermenting yeast from a world famous Czech pilsner.  Produces a dry, clean beer.   Perfect for pilsner and other lager styles.  This yeast is flocculent and produces a very clear beer.  Robust attenuation in beer up to 16-17˚ Plato.  Moderate to poor attenuation in very high gravity beers (over 20˚ Plato).

name: Achouffe Belgian
best_for: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde
notes: Abbey style yeast from the Belgian Ardennes. Produces aromatic, spicy clove-like notes and less fruity aromas than GY014. Moderately flocculant yeast that creates a slightly clearer beer than most Belgians.

name: Golden Gate Lager
best_for: California Common, Cream Ale, Stout
notes: Lager yeast used to create the California Common beer style.  Ferments unusually high for a lager strain and still retains a lager sensibility (up to 68˚F).  This yeast leaves a slightly sweeter beer than our other lager yeast— perfect for creating a subtle, malty undertone against a clean lager background.  Creates a moderate amount of sulfide under some conditions that will dissipate with a short rest.  Fermentations at traditional lager temperatures may be slow.  Recommended 55˚- 68˚F

name: Belgian Mix
best_for: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde, Saison
notes: A blend of Trappist Ale Yeast combine to create robust attenuation and a complex flavor profile.  Spicy and fruity, this blend is slightly more flocculent than many Belgians.  Good choice for High Gravity beers.

name: British Ale Yeast One
best_for: British ales, Pale ale, Amber ale, Barley wine, Scotch ale, Bitter, Stout, IPA
notes: Versatile house strain from a traditional UK brewery.  Strong attenuation over a broad temperature range and low esters make this yeast perfect for a wide variety of styles.  GY011 is a strong flocculator that creates a clear beer.

name: Scourmont Abbey
best_for: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Beire de Garde, Saison
notes: Classic Belgian yeast from one of the best known Trappist breweries.  A fragrant yeast that produces delicious fruity aroma.  Good choice for high gravity beers.  Generally, the warmer this yeast is fermented the higher the level of fruit aromas produced.

name: Trappist Tripel
best_for: Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Belgian Strong, Tripel, Biere de Garde, Saison
notes: Trappist Ale yeast from the mother of all Tripels.  A balance of fruit and spice with a  good malty finish provides a perfect complement for Belgian Ales, Dubbels and Tripels.   Attenuation is on the slow side leaving more residual sweetness than our other Belgians. Less esters and phenolics than GY003 and GY014.

name: Altstadt Ale
best_for: Kolsch, California Common, Altbier, Biere de Garde, Cream Ale
notes: An ale yeast that ferments at cold temperatures and produces a lager like ale style with a hint of fruity esters.  Leaves a slight residual maltiness perfect for traditional Kölsch and Alt styles.

name: Bavarian Hefe
best_for: Dunkelweizen, Gose, Hefeweizen, Weizenbock
notes: A traditional hefe yeast from one of Bavaria’s oldest breweries.  Robust attenuator that works over a broad range of temperatures and produces the classic banana and clove notes of the German wheat beer style.  Moderate sulfide producer (will dissipate with conditioning).

name: Saison Yeast One
best_for: Saison, Farmhouse Ale, Belgian Ale, Biere de Garde
notes: Traditional Saison yeast from a French craft brewery.  Produces fragrant beer with pepper and fruit notes.  Warmer fermentations create more intense flavors.   Perfect for accentuating citrus and fruit flavors.  High attenuation rates make a dryer beer than Saison #2

name: Portland Hefe
